Award.AwardTitle: STEM Scholars - Building Professional Identities in Under-Represented Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
STEM Scholars - Building Professional Identities in Under-Represented Students

The goal of the project is to increase the number of distinguished underrepresented STEM graduates from the University of Wisconsin-Platteville. To accomplish this, females and underrepresented minorities (URMs) will be supported through large scholarships and high-impact practices, enabling them to be academically successful in STEM majors, acquire career development skills, participate in undergraduate internship experience(s), and to secure desirable STEM job placements upon graduation.

The intellectual merit of this program is refining campus best practices for recruiting and retaining underrepresented students. Innovative practices will be employed, including the use of non-cognitive traits to demonstrate academic potential and to personalize support programming for students, development of a cohort network of support through shared scheduling of classes and shared extracurricular experiences, and a strong peer mentor support system. Additional best practices will include the building of early networks with industry champions, student development that includes career placement initiatives, and building the campus' overall institutional capacity for student success among academic and student services and also industry. This capacity-building effort also will have broader impact implications.

The broader impacts of this project will help creating a legacy of STEM Scholars on campus and improving degree attainment for underrepresented students in the College of EMS. This project is also augmenting the campus' pipeline of underrepresented populations into STEM professions. Finally, through existing and developing industry relationships, the project will improve faculty and industry partners' competency in supporting underrepresented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project include:

  1. Recruit and select academically talented female and/or underrepresented minority students with demonstrated financial need.
  2. Create a unified cohort identity that engages the scholars to build a sense of community.
  3. Initiate and develop professional identity in scholars.
  4. Develop scholars noncognitive transferable skills related to self-efficacy, intercultural communication, lifelong learning, teamwork, setting and attaining goals, and leadership.
  5. Support all scholars from enrollment through degree attainment and desired job or graduate school placement.
  6. Synthesize existing best practices (such as use of noncognitive variables in applicant selection; development of cohort identity; individualized support programming; and progressive career development) into a holistic approach to degree attainment and desired job or graduate school placement. [Intellectual Merit]
  7. Advance institutional capacity for preparing diverse and competitive graduates, increasing the presence of underrepresented groups among the broader STEM community. [Broader Impact]
  8. Use a value-added assessment approach to determine the impact of this program on degree attainment and desired job or graduate school placement. [Intellectual Merit]

Specific Outcomes include:

Retained through graduation. Eight scholars have graduated with STEM degrees; 4 scholars graduated in 4 years, two scholars graduated in 4.5 years, and 2 scholars graduated in 5 years or more.

Retention in STEM. Participation correlates to substantial increases in retention of students in STEM through four years or graduation, specifically:

  • 88% (comparative is 51%) for the entire cohort; 
  • 7 of 8 female identifying scholars 88% (comparative is 51%); 
  • 6 of 8 underrepresented minority identifying scholars 75% (comparative is 43%).

Successful STEM-related post-graduate placement. Overall, 8 of 9 (89%) of graduated scholars have gainful employment or are enrolled in a graduate program, while 10 of 13 scholars (77%) will have gainful employment or be enrolled in a graduate program by the start of summer 2021.

Value of Scholarship and Programming. Scholars highly valued the financial support (100% as #1 in value and #1 in impact), career development and readiness (#2 in value and #3 in impact), mentorship (4 explicitly stated that this helped them get through a difficult time which impacted their retention), and personal identity development (#3 in most impactful) to have the greatest impact.

Fostered a strong sense of community among scholars. Two themes emerged: familiarity among peers, and the community atmosphere while allowing for individual growth. The sense of community and familiarity among peers was developed through a short Summer Bridge program prior to the start of their first semester; cohort courses during the first semester, and the one-credit seminar which brought the scholars together one time each week, every semester during the program. Scholars indicated that seeing familiar faces and talking to peers provided a sense of comfort and support, and a level of accountability. One hundred percent of the scholars reported the program made them feel less isolated in comparison to their UW-Platteville experiences outside the program.

Development and improvement of professional skills.  Scholars reported that goal setting and reflection and improving study skills were very beneficial. The focus on teaching scholars how to maximize faculty interactions helped to build scholar confidence and comfort in engaging with faculty and utilizing them as valuable resources. The goal setting and reflection was stated as beneficial and a direct application for their professional career. One scholar discussed how the goal setting and reflection allowed them to ?rock their interview? because they had already taken the time to reflect about the questions that were asked of them. The service-learning project recevied high impact ratings towards personal development. Scholars spoke highly of the project helping to develop their teamwork, communication, organization, and leadership skills, and supporting their emotional growth.

Scholars found Program a very important reason for success. There were no program components that had an average score below 3.75 out of 5.00  and out of the 16 program components, (88%) had an average ranking of 4.00 or higher with a cumulative ranking average of 4.42. Scholars ranked the Program (4.80) much higher than UW-Platteville in general (3.80) with regards to professional skills in future jobs (Cohen?s d = 0.88). Overall, 10 of 12 (83%) of scholars surveyed indicated that the Program was the most important program they were a part of while at UW-Platteville, while (2/12) 17% valued the program as equally important. Scholars overwhelmingly found the program played an important role (based on a 5-point Likert scale) in their academic success, post-graduate placement, and overall well-being (4.35, 4.17, 4.08, respectively). For two of the scholars, it was the financial support that enabled them to attend UW-Platteville. Additionally, because of the financial support, 3 out of 12 (25%) of the surveyed scholars left or will be leaving college debt free, and 8 of 12 (67%) have debt of $25K or less. Just one scholar graduated with a debt greater than $25K.
